item.title: Connection Defender - js13k
item.description: I have entered js13k this year. It is a javascript game competition in which the total game size must be less than 13kb. You can checkout my entry at the following url: https://js13kgames.com/entries/connection-defender.

item.title: Introducing hypo-container
item.description: A dependency injection container. Supports NodeJS and browser development.

item.title: A 'Doggie Movie'
item.description: In recent weeks online privacy has been a hot topic. I say this in relation to the Facebook/Cambridge Analytica fiasco.

item.title: Hacking The Github Activity Graph
item.description: This article covers how to hack the activity graph that appears on each github user’s profile using fake commits.

item.title: Using Property Accessors
item.description: Accessors, also known as getters/setters, provide a way of intercepting access to object properties. They are supported in Javascript and Typescript via the get and set keywords.

item.title: Large Number Addition in Javascript
item.description: Javascript supports at most 53 bit integers. What this means is that integers larger than 53 bits lose precision. This article will explain how to handle addition with integers larger than 53 bits in javascript.

item.title: Using Vue Class Components
item.description: The Vue Class Component module provides a component decorator which can inject properties into Vue components. This allows developers to create components which make use of javascript’s natural language constructs. The more native syntax helps with readability and developer understanding. Which ultimately contributes to maintainability.

item.title: Http to Https Redirect in Node
item.description: Node comes with https support out of the box. This article will explain how to redirect your http traffic to https. Express 4 will be used to demo this. The code examples will be written in Typescript.

item.title: ES6 DOM Scripting Tricks
item.description: In this post we are going to make use of some ES6 features in regards to DOM scripting. Features like destructuring, the spread operator, and the for..of loop lend themselves well to DOM scripting.

item.title: Canvas Fireworks Using Javascript
item.description: This post is a tutorial explaining how to code a fireworks display using the canvas element. No external libraries or frameworks will be necessary.

item.title: Using Typescript with Node
item.description: In this article we will set up an Express application using Typescript.

item.title: Parsing a Panda With Elixir
item.description: I attended the first Edinburgh Elixir meet-up on Monday. It was a great social event with around ~20 attendees. Most of which were first time Elixir users.

item.title: The Crockford Invocation
item.description: In this post we are going to look at some common invocation patterns used in javascript. We will then examine how they can be improved using ES6 syntax.

item.title: Fire, Snow, and Rain Canvas Effects
item.description: All three of the demos below are written in Typescript and make use of the browser’s canvas element. No external libraries are used and each example is made up of around 100 lines of code.

item.title: Whats New in ES2016 (ES7)
item.description: ES6 introduced a huge number of improvements to Javascript. It was the first major update to the language since 2009 and It was due to this that so many features were added.

item.title: Creating Fractals
item.description: Fractals show the beauty of numbers. There are many famous fractals, which are often named after European mathematicians. You may have heard of Sierpinski’s Triangle, the Mandelbrot Set, and the Koch Curve. These are all fractal patterns.

item.title: Hi, My name is Brian
item.description: I am a Software Engineer living and working in Donegal, Ireland. I have a Master’s degree in Computer Science and am always looking to learn new things related to programming. I mostly program in Typescript, Javascript, and PHP. Though I always have an eye on new languages and frameworks that I would like to learn. Feel free to check out my current projects on github. My username is BrianDGLS.
